title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 provides specifications for the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin shall have a designation of its value, an inscription of the year "1995". The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The design shall include inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Act allows for the issuance of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a single Mint facility. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. Additionally, the Act permits the sale of these coins. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, with surcharges provided for. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount before the issuance of such coins. Sales under this subsection shall be at a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $10 per coin is required for all sales. - General waiver of procurement regulations.
- No law governing procurement or public contracts applies to goods or services necessary for this Act.
- Nothing in this section relieves a person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with equal employment opportunity laws.
- Distribution of surcharges: All surcharges received from coin sales under this Act shall be promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.
- Audits. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. This Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins with specific specifications. The coins will feature a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade design. They will contain 90% silver and 10% copper and be legal tender. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, struck at one US Mint facility, and issued from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity requirements.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.

SEC. 9. AUDITS.

The Comptroller General can audit the National Fund's expenditures related to surcharges.
